title: Print & Input
description: Learn how to display output and get user input

content.text: The print() function is how you display information in Python. You've already used it, but let's explore what it can do!

content.explanation: Each print() statement displays text on a new line. Text must be in quotes to be a string.

content.text: You can print multiple things at once by separating them with commas:

content.code:
name = "Alice"
age = 25

print("Name:", name)
print("Age:", age)
print("Name:", name, "Age:", age)
content.explanation: print() automatically adds spaces between items when you separate them with commas.

content.text: F-strings (formatted strings) are a powerful way to insert variables into text:

content.code:
name = "Bob"
age = 30
city = "New York"

print(f"My name is {name}")
print(f"I am {age} years old")
print(f"{name} lives in {city} and is {age} years old")
content.explanation: Put 'f' before the quote and use {variable_name} to insert variables. This is the modern, clean way to format strings in Python.

content.text: F-strings are better than using + to join strings because they're easier to read and work with any data type automatically!
You can do math inside f-strings:

content.code:
price = 20
quantity = 3

print(f"Total: ${price * quantity}")
print(f"Price per item: ${price}")
content.explanation: Python calculates the expression inside {} before inserting it into the string.

content.text: The input() function lets you get information from users:

content.code:
# Note: input() works differently in the browser
# In real Python, this would wait for user input
name = "Alice"  # Simulating user input
print(f"Hello, {name}!")
content.explanation: In real Python, input() pauses and waits for the user to type something. In the browser, we simulate it with variables.

content.text: input() always returns a string (text), even if the user types a number. You'll need to convert it if you want to do math!

content.code:
# Simulating user input
age_text = "25"

# Convert string to integer
age = int(age_text)

print(f"Next year you'll be {age + 1}")
print(f"In 10 years you'll be {age + 10}")
content.explanation: int() converts a string to an integer. Without this conversion, you can't do math with the input!

content.prompt: Create variables for a person's first name, last name, and age. Use an f-string to print a sentence like: 'John Doe is 25 years old.'
content.starter:
# Create your variables

# Print the sentence using an f-string
content.solution:
# Create your variables
first_name = "John"
last_name = "Doe"
age = 25

# Print the sentence using an f-string
print(f"{first_name} {last_name} is {age} years old.")
content.hint: Remember to put 'f' before the opening quote and use {variable} to insert variables into the string.

content.text: Excellent! You now know how to display information with print() and format strings with f-strings. Next, we'll learn about math operations!
